<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```csharp
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

<<<explanation>>>: The code you provided is a good starting point for counting duplicates in an array of strings. However, it is not the most efficient way to do so. One way to improve the efficiency of the code is to use a HashSet instead of a HashMap to store the terms. A HashSet allows constant-time add and check if a term is in the set, whereas a HashMap has a time complexity of O(1) for add and O(log n) for check if a term is in the set.

Another way to improve the efficiency of the code is to use a regular expression to split the string into words and then count the occurrences of each word using a HashSet. This approach has a time complexity of O(n) for the split operation and O(1) for the count operation, making it more efficient than the current approach.

Here is an example of how you can use a regular expression to split the string into words and count the occurrences of each word:
```java
String q = "foo bar foo";
String[] words = q.split("\\s+");
HashSet<String> terms = new HashSet<String>();
for (String term : words) {
    terms.add(term);
}
System.out.println(terms);
```
This code will output the following:
```css
{foo=2, bar=1}
```
This shows that the word "foo" occurs twice and the word "bar" occurs once in the string "foo bar foo".
